parts: A 1952 issue of Time magazine declared that this river "oozes rather than flows" through Cleveland. It infamously caught on fire in 1969.

26 million fish were killed in this state in 1969 due to pollution from food processing plants. The Marjorie Harris Carr Greenway in this state runs along some of the route of a cancelled cross-state canal.
Sports fans in this New England city still sing "Dirty Water," a song by The Standells partially inspired by the pollution in the Charles River.

answers: Du Fu [or Tu Fu; or Zimei; accept Du Shaoling; accept Du Gongbu; accept Shaoling Yelao]
"Song of the Wagons" [or such translations as "Song of the War Chariots" and "Ballad of the Army Carts"; accept "bīng chē xíng"]
parts: Name this Chinese poet who wrote “Thinking of Li Bai at the End of the Sky.”
The An Lushan rebellion inspired this Du Fu poem, which opens with whinnying horses and the rumbling title objects covering a bridge in the dust they stir up.
Du Fu, who died in 770 CE, wrote during this dynasty. Li Bai also wrote during this dynasty, considered the Golden Age of Chinese poetry.

answers: inversion [or inverted chords; accept first inversion]
augmented sixth [accept Italian, French, or German sixth]
parts: Voicing often refers to the orientation of notes in one of these musical configurations, which are sets of notes heard simultaneously. These entities can comprise progressions that drive harmonic development.
This term is used to describe chords whose lowest note is not the root note. For example, a C major chord in the "first" variant of this term uses E as its lowest note instead of C.

When voicing chords, the doubling of notes must be performed deliberately. For example, when voicing augmented chords of this numerical interval –– variants of which are called Italian, French, and German –– the interval’s notes should not be doubled, but the tonic pitch should be.
A lobster's longevity may come from their production of this enzyme that repairs the end of chromosomes.
Turritopsis dohrnii is an "immortal" type of this cnidarian because it can continually cycle from polyp to medusa and back. Some "box" species of this animal have a particularly venomous sting.
Biologically immortal organisms must be able to avoid this phenomenon in which cell division ceases. The replicative form of this phenomenon occurs at the Hayflick limit.

answers: x-rays film [accept x-radiation; prompt on radiation or imaging]
parts: Name this non-fiction book that traces the title system from 1918 until a thaw in 1956. This book describes the typical life of a zek.
This Soviet intelligence agency, whose name means Committee for State Security, was ordered to assassinate Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn with ricin to prevent him from finishing the Gulag Archipelago.
The Gulag Archipelago circulated as underground samizdat. Samizdat music records were often published on film intended for use with this technology, invented by Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen.
Name this subject who was classically conditioned to develop a phobia of furry, white objects.

John B. Watson built on the fame from the Little Albert experiment to get a lucrative gig in the ad industry. This critic argued that advertisers were using subliminal messaging to manipulate the public in his 1957 book The Hidden Persuaders.
Watson's Kerplunk experiment was named for the sound rats made when one of these structures was shortened. Tyron's Rat Experiment examined how quickly rats could complete one of these puzzles.
Name this plastic deformation caused by prolonged loading.

The general equation governing creep relates strain rate to this function of the quantity activation energy over RT. Other phenomena modeled with this function include capacitor discharge and radioactive decay.
Coble and Nabarro-Herring creep both occur via solid-state forms of this process. This process's associated constant equals mobility times k-sub-B times T by the Einstein-Smoluchowski relation.

answers: The Good Soldier Svejk [or The Good Soldier Svejk: And His Fortunes in the World War; or The Fateful Adventures of the Good Soldier Svejk During the World War; or Osudy dobrého vojáka Švejka za světové války]
parts: Name this unfinished satirical novel whose title character is arrested by a secret policeman after discussing flies defecating on a portrait of Emperor Franz Joseph I.
The Good Soldier Svejk was written in this language. Milan Kundera wrote The Unbearable Lightness of Being in this language, although he now writes in French.
Before joining the army, Svejk earned his living by stealing these creatures. One of these creatures is transformed into Poligraf Poligrafovich in a Mikhail Bulgakov novel.

Anand Giridharadas ("gih-rih-dar-uh-DOSS") argued that historians should stop writing "from the viewpoint of 30,000 feet" in a review of this man's most recent work, Upheaval. This man is best-known for Guns, Germs and Steel.
This Israeli historian's Sapiens starts with the Cognitive Revolution which "kick-started history 70,000 years ago" and extends to the Scientific Revolution.

Bill Bryson, who wrote a book titled A Short History of Nearly Everything, wrote a travelogue of this country titled In a Sunburned Country. Thomas Kenneally's The Commonwealth of Thieves is a history of this one-time convict colony.

answers: Price [accept Mary Violet Leontyne Price; accept Florence Beatrice Price]
parts: Name this opera, which includes characters such as the pianist Jasbo Brown, the honey merchant Peter, and a drug dealer who sings "It Ain't Necessarily So."
Blue's interpretation of this Porgy and Bess aria, which declares that "the livin' is easy" during its title season, has been hailed for its unique musical embellishments.

Blue has been compared to the Met's first African-American prima donna, who had this last name. A Black woman composer with this married surname premiered her pioneering First Symphony in Chicago in 1933.

answers: p [accept potential, power, Potenz, puissance, pouvoir, potentia, or pondus; prompt on, but do not reveal, pH]
H+ ("H plus") [or the hydrogen cation; accept hydrogen one plus, hydrons or protons; prompt on pH]
parts: Name this letter which was chosen to refer to a specific electrode, unless it was chosen to mean a word in German, or one in French, or one in Latin. This letter indicates the use of the cologarithm function with base 10.
By far the most common use of p in chemistry is to represent the number of these ions in solution, which quantifies how acidic something is.
Though often studied as a precursor to the Lewis concept, this acid-base theory that focuses on the donation of H+ was developed in the same year.

answers: Coney Island [accept A Coney Island of the Mind]
parts: Name this New York location that titles a collection featuring the poems "Junkman's Obbligato" and "I am Waiting."
This author's time in Mexico City inspired his poem "Mexico City Blues." Dean abandons Sal Paradise in Mexico City in this author's novel On the Road.
Allen Ginsberg's brief stay in this mental institution inspired a repeated line that tells Carl Solomon "I'm with you" in this place in the poem "Howl."

answers: Southern Baptist Convention [or SBC; prompt on Baptists]
parts: Name this denomination founded in 1845 in opposition to anti-slavery efforts by other members of the Triennial Convention.
In this epistle, Paul declares that he is sending back Onesimus ("o-NEH-sih-muhs"), who is "no longer a slave, but something beyond a slave," with instructions to welcome Onesimus as himself.

This patriarch's curse on Ham's son Canaan, erroneously called the "Curse of Ham," has been used by some Christians to justify white supremacy and the enslavement of Black people. This prophet and his family survived the Flood.

"Mrs. M" was a close behind-the-scenes advisor to this Governor of New York. This man, nicknamed the “Happy Warrior,” opposed prohibition before leading the company that built the Empire State Building.

Lewis Hine, who was hired by Moskowitz to photograph illegal dance houses, photographed these people working in the Carolinas. Before it was outlawed, these people were used as mine trappers because of their small size.

Moskowitz began her career working at the Educational Alliance, one of these places for Jewish immigrants. The first American woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize founded the most prominent one of these places in the US.

answers: Metropolitan Museum of Art [or The Met]
parts: Identify this term from art history that traces the history of previous owners of a work of art.
This New York museum ended its exhibition Nedjemankh ("neh-jeh-MANK”) and His Gilded Coffin due to false provenance records. This largest US art museum displays a reconstructed Temple of Dendur.

Andre Breton questioned the provenance of this artist’s painting of a sleeping Romani woman after it was purchased by Alfred Barr for the MOMA. In that work, this artist painted a lion passing by an exhausted woman under the moonlight.

answers: k-nearest neighbors algorithm [accept k-nearest neighbors classification or k-nearest neighbors regression; accept k-NN in place of "k-nearest neighbors"]
weighted [or weighting; accept weighted average or weighted arithmetic mean]
logistic [or logit; accept logistic regression or logistic curve; accept logistic function; do not accept or prompt on "log" or "logarithmic"]
parts: Name this classification algorithm where nearby points in the training set vote on an input's classification.

This type of voting scheme can compensate for skew in k-NN by making some votes worth more. Similarly, this type of average may give your tests greater importance than other scores when calculating your math grade.

This adjective describes a regression technique that assumes the log-odds of an event and its predictor variables are linearly related. This type of function is given by the equation (read slowly) one over the quantity one plus e to the negative x.

answers: Hugo Chavez [or Hugo Rafael Chávez Frías]
parts: Identify this oil-producing country, the birthplace of revolutionary "precursor" Francisco de Miranda.
This Venezuelan president revived the cult of Guaicaipuro. His "Bolivarian Revolution" has proven less successful under his successor, Nicolas Maduro.

Venezuela, like Uruguay and Peru, has a far-left political party named for this man, born José Gabriel Condorcanqui ("con-dor-CAN-kee”), who led a failed revolt against the Spanish in the 1780s. This man took his name from the last Incan ruler.

answers: warden of Hiram's Hospital [accept The Warden]
parts: Name this author who included his novel Barchester Towers in his Barsetshire series.
Barchester Towers opens in the aftermath of Septimus Harding having resigned this lucrative position at Hiram's Hospital. This post titles the first novel in the Barsetshire series.
Trollope befriended this author while writing his Barsetshire series, later going on to write a biography of him. This author wrote about the mischievous Becky Sharp in his novel Vanity Fair.

answers: Cupertino [or Copertino] (the saint is Joseph of Cupertino, also the patron saint of astronauts)
parts: Name this man who kills his younger rival in an Alexander Pushkin play and narrates his story from a mental asylum in a Milos Forman film.

Salieri is described as the "patron saint of mediocrities" in Forman's Amadeus. The closest real saint may be Joseph, a patron saint of poor students who hails from this city. Another city of this name is Apple's California headquarters.
Amadeus playwright Peter Shaffer also wrote Equus, a play about a young man obsessed with one of these creatures, which come in varieties such as thoroughbreds.

answers: hanging in the air [or hanging from a tree; accept equivalents mentioning hanging or being suspended midair]
parts: Name this god. Rhea gave Cronus a stone to swallow instead of this god, who later defeated Cronus to become king of the gods.
Since Cronus ruled sea, sky, and land, Zeus' cradle was hidden in this manner to avoid Cronus' detection. A description is fine.
Zeus spent his childhood in a cave on a Cretan mountain with this name. Zeus abducted Ganymede from a mountain of this name near Troy.

answers: Arthur Ashe [or Arthur Robert Ashe Jr.]
parts: Identify this first Black man to win the US Open and Wimbledon. He died of AIDS in 1993.

Ashe called a press conference to announce he had AIDS to pre-empt a story by this newspaper. This "McPaper" achieved a circulation of over 5 million by the late 1980s, making it Gannett's best-selling paper.
After much debate, a statue of Ashe was erected on Monument Avenue in this city, Ashe's hometown. J.E.B. Stuart's statue was removed from this capital of the Confederacy in 2020.
